title: Pediatric obsessive-compulsive disorder with tic symptoms: clinical presentation and treatment outcome
abstract:
of CBT. Children and adolescents with OCD and co-morbid tic symptoms differ from those without tic symptoms in several aspects of clinical presentation, but not in their response to CBT. Our results underscore the effectiveness of CBT for tic-related OCD.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.text:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a clinically heterogeneous disorder; its symptoms have been shown to present in several distinct dimensions  [1] . Common in children and adolescents, OCD has a prevalence rate between 1 and 4%  [2] [3] [4] [5] . Some of the most common co-morbid disorders in pediatric OCD are tic disorders-Tourette disorder, chronic motor or vocal tic disorder, and transient tic disorder-with a prevalence rate in the pediatric OCD population of 20-59% [6-9]. In the general population, the prevalence of tic disorders is between 1 and 5%  [10] , with chronic tic disorder between 1 and 2% while 5% experience transient tic disorders  [11] . OCD is commonly seen as a comorbid disorder in children and adolescents with tic disorders  [12] . In the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5)  [13] , tic disorder was added as a specifier for OCD, to be given in cases of current or past tic disorders  [14] .

Studies have suggested that OCD and co-morbid tic disorders are more frequently seen in males  [15] . A study by  Lewin et al.  found that 63% of OCD patients with Abstract Some studies have shown that children and adolescents with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and co-morbid tics differ from those without co-morbid tics in terms of several demographic and clinical characteristics. However, not all studies have confirmed these differences. This study examined children and adolescents with OCD and with possible or definite tic specifiers according to the DSM-5 in order to see whether they differ from patients without any tic symptoms regarding clinical presentation and outcome of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). The full sample included 269 patients (aged 7-17) with primary DSM-IV OCD who had participated in the Nordic Long-term Treatment Study (NordLOTS). Symptoms of tics were assessed using the Kiddie Schedule for Affective Disorders and Schizophrenia (K-SADS-PL). One or more tic symptoms were found in 29.9% of participants. Those with OCD and co-morbid tic symptoms were more likely male, more likely to have onset of OCD at an earlier age, and differed in terms of OCD symptom presentation. More specifically, such participants also showed more symptoms of OCD-related impairment, externalization, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), social anxiety, and attention-deficit/ hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). However, the two groups showed no difference in terms of OCD severity or outcome co-morbid tic disorder were men, compared to 59% of those without co-morbid tic disorder  [15] . Comparing OCD without tic symptoms to OCD with any tic symptoms (that did not fulfill the criteria for tic disorder) found an even bigger gender difference, 39.6% of males had OCD without tic symptoms versus 53% with OCD with co-morbid symptoms of tics  [16] . In adults, studies have shown that OCD patients with co-morbid tic disorders have obsessive and compulsive symptoms of elevated severity  [17] , but pediatric studies have not confirmed this relationship  [8, 15, 16] . Although children and adolescents with OCD suffer from considerable functional impairment  [18] [19] [20] [21] , and reduced quality of life  [22] , the presence of co-morbid tics has not been shown to aggravate functional impairment in this group  [15] , however, studies in this regard are few and have limited power.

Several studies have shown that the type of obsessivecompulsive symptoms among patients with OCD differs between those with and without co-morbid tics. One study found that OCD patients with co-morbid tics have fewer ordering, hoarding, and washing compulsions; however, this study did not report differences in obsessions  [8] , partially resembling findings from an earlier study on adults by Holzer et al.  [23] . Results from another study indicated that children and adolescents with OCD and co-morbid tic disorders had considerably fewer contamination obsessions, sexual obsessions, and counting compulsions  [24] . Both of these studies had limited sample sizes. An epidemiological study found that adolescents with OCD and co-morbid tics had more symptoms of violent images and impulses but fewer sexual symptoms than those having OCD without tics  [25] . In a more recent study, children and adolescents with OCD and co-morbid tic symptoms displayed lower rates of religious obsessions and of washing and ordering compulsions, but this study had the limitation that all participants were partial and/or non-responders to previous SRI treatment  [16] . As the results of these studies vary considerably, we cannot make firm conclusions concerning specific patterns of OCD symptoms. However, the particular symptom, "doing things until they feel just right," also referred to as "not just right experiences," has been shown to occur more frequently in OCD patients of all ages with co-morbid tic disorders and/or autism spectrum disorder  [23, 26, 27] , although in one study "just right experiences" were reported to be related to OCD severity but not tics  [28] .

Co-morbidity of OCD and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is well known, primarily in young populations, but the theoretical account for this connection remains unclear  [29] . Some researchers have suggested that co-morbidity between OCD and ADHD could be mediated by the presence of tic disorders  [30] . Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and autism spectrum traits are more prevalent in child and adolescent OCD than in the general population, and both are linked to co-morbidity of attention/ behavioral disorders and tics  [31, 32] . A recent study found that OCD patients with tics have higher rates of ADHD and ODD/CD but lower rates of anxiety disorders, specifically generalized anxiety and separation anxiety  [15] . However, contrary to this finding, a more recent study found no significant differences in other co-morbidities between young patients with OCD and co-morbid tic symptoms and those with no tic symptoms  [16] . Collectively, prior results are somewhat mixed, but the pattern of co-morbidity does seem to be different for children and adolescents with OCD and co-morbid tics compared to those with OCD and no tics.

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an effective treatment for OCD  [33] [34] [35] , resulting in improved quality of life  [36] . It has been suggested that patients with tic-related OCD might benefit less from standard OCD treatment programs, further implying that this subgroup of patients should receive treatment especially modified to target the specific OCDsymptom profile of this group  [37] . Albeit, to our knowledge, this assumption has not been confirmed in any OCD treatment studies on children and adolescents  [8, [38] [39] [40] [41] [42] [43] . It has been found, however, that children and adolescents with OCD and a co-morbid tic disorder do show reduced benefit from pharmacotherapy with SRI/SSRI compared to CBT  [38, [44] [45] [46] , or no difference at all  [47, 48] . Conversely, one study suggested that non-responders to CBT with OCD and tics derive added benefit from SSRI pharmacotherapy compared to continued CBT  [49] . To our knowledge, only one study has examined broadly defined tic symptoms as a predictor of treatment efficacy, finding no significant differences in the effects of CBT treatment between OCD patients with and without tic symptoms  [16] . Limitations of this study, however, are that patients were not treatment naïve and did not receive standalone CBT but rather received one of medication management, medication management with instructions in CBT, or a combination of medical management and full CBT  [16] .

Taken together, studies of tic symptoms as predictors of treatment outcome are scarce, and, from the only study investigating broadly defined tic symptoms, no conclusions can be drawn regarding youth untreated for OCD, because that study concerned partial responders to SRI treatment. Differences in the clinical presentation of OCD with tic symptoms could give clinicians valuable information about treatment for this group of patients, since tic symptoms are now an OCD specifier according to the DSM-5  [13] .

In this study, we define tic symptoms widely and in accordance with the DSM-5 in order to embrace a broad group having tic symptoms and OCD. Having a current or past possible, probable, definite or partially remitted diagnosis of a tics disorder and/or Tourette's syndrome was enough to classify a participant into this OCD + tic group.

This study had two aims:  (1)  to examine (in a non-treated group) whether children and adolescents with OCD and cooccurring, broadly defined tic symptoms compared to children and adolescents with OCD and without co-occurring tics differ with respect to age, gender, age of OCD onset, symptom profile, or co-morbidity, and (2) to evaluate whether the two groups respond differently to CBT.

Based on the literature, we hypothesized that children and adolescents with co-morbid tic symptoms would: (1) be predominantly male with an earlier age of onset, (2) have higher rates of co-morbid behavioral disorders and autism spectrum traits, and (3) have a different profile of OCD symptom presentation. However, we did not expect these groups to differ in terms of: (4) OCD severity, (5) functional impairment, or (6) benefit derived from CBT.

sections.title: Participants
sections.text: The sample included 269 children and adolescents aged 7-17 from the Nordic Long-term Treatment Study (Nord-LOTS)  [50] . In the full NordLOTS sample, one patient had missing data on tic symptoms and was therefore excluded. All participants were diagnosed with OCD according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, Text Revision (DSM-IV-TR) and had a Children's Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (CY-BOCS) score greater than or equal to 16. Participants were recruited between September 2008 and May 2012 from 20 clinics in Norway, Denmark, and Sweden. Mean age in years was 12.8 (SD = 2.7) and 48.9% were male. Exclusion criteria were any co-morbid disorder with higher treatment priority according to the Clinical Global Impressions-Severity (CGI-S), particularly pervasive developmental disorder (PDD; i.e., Asperger's disorder or autism spectrum disorder). PDD-NOS patients were included if they were more impaired by OCD symptoms than by PDD symptoms. The study was approved by the Danish, Norwegian and Swedish national ethical committees, and informed consent was obtained from all participants. A more detailed description of the sample may be found elsewhere  [33, 50] .

sections.title: Children's Yale-Brown obsessive compulsive scale (CY-BOCS)
sections.text: CY-BOCS is a semi-structured interview estimating OCD severity and symptom presentation and comprising two parts. The first part is a 74-item checklist assessing a broad range of obsessions and compulsions, both current and past. The second part consists of 10 questions (five regarding obsessions and five regarding compulsions) measuring severity on a 5-point scale, with a total score ranging 1-40  [51] . The CY-BOCS has been shown to have reliability and validity in samples of children  [52] . In the NordLOTS study, the intra-class correlation coefficients (ICC) of interrater agreement were: obsessions ICC = 0.94 (95% CI 0.85-0.97), compulsions ICC = 0.87 (95% CI 0.67-0.93), and total score ICC = 0.92 (95% CI 0.78-0.97) [50] .

sections.title: Kiddie schedule for affective disorders and schizophrenia (K-SADS-PL)
sections.text: K-SADS-PL is a semi-structured, diagnostic interview designed to assess a broad range of child and adolescent mental disorders according to DSM-IV criteria. The interview consists of an introductory interview, a screening interview, and a diagnostic part. Symptoms are scored as "not present," "possible," "in remission," or "certain"  [53] . K-SADS-PL has been shown to possess good inter-rater reliability (98%) and a 1-5 week test-retest kappa of 0.80 for all anxiety diagnoses  [53] . Good convergent and divergent validity has been shown in a Nordic sample of adolescents  [54] . Concerning co-morbid disorders, only diagnoses classified as "certain" were used in this study, except for chronic motor or vocal tic disorder, transient tic disorder and Tourette's disorder. For these diagnoses the classifications "possible", "probable", "partially remitted" and "past" were also included.

sections.title: The child obsessive-compulsive impact scale (COIS-R)
sections.text: COIS-R is a 33-item self-reported questionnaire used to assess the impact of OCD symptoms on the psychosocial functioning of children and adolescents in home, school, and social settings. Both parent and child rating versions are available. Items are scored on a 4-point Likert scale (0 = not at all, 1 = just a little, 2 = pretty much, and 3 = very much). Both versions of the scale have shown moderate to high internal consistency, α = 0.92-0.94 and α = 0.78-0.92 for the parent and child versions, respectively  [21, 55] .

sections.title: Child behavior checklist (CBCL)
sections.text: CBCL assesses a wide range of child behavioral and emotional problems. Rated by parents, it has 113 items on a 3-point scale (0 = not true, 1 = somewhat or sometimes true, and 2 = very or often true). The instrument has been shown to have good psychometric properties across different populations, and the scale has shown a mean test-retest reliability between 0.95 and 1.00 and an internal consistency from α = 0.78 to α = 0.97  [41, 56] .

sections.title: The mood and feelings questionnaire (MFQ)
sections.text: MFQ measures symptoms of depression based on DSM-III-R. It comprises 13 items and has a scoring range from 0 to 26  [57] . The scale has good psychometric properties, and the scale's total score has an internal consistency of α = 0.75 to α = 0.90  [41, 58, 59] .

sections.title: Autism spectrum screening questionnaire (ASSQ)
sections.text: Used to measure symptoms of autism spectrum disorders, ASSQ consists of 27 items rated on a 3-point scale (0 = no, 1 = somewhat, and 2 = yes) referring to the degree of severity. The scale's total score ranges from 0 to 54 and has been found to have an internal consistency of α = 0.86  [60] . The ASSQ has been proven to be a reliable and valid screening instrument for both clinical and general populations  [61, 62] , and good internal consistency has been demonstrated for the language versions used in this study  [32] .

sections.title: Screen for child-anxiety-related emotional disorders (SCARED)
sections.text: SCARED is a questionnaire designed to measure symptoms of anxiety based on DSM-IV criteria. Scored from 0 to 82, its total score has been found to have an internal consistency of α = 0.92 for both child-and parent-rated versions  [41] .

sections.title: Data analysis
sections.text: Independent t test was used to examine the difference between groups regarding age and CY-BOCS scores. For comparison of other assessments, the Mann-Whitney test was used, because these others did not have normal distributions of data. To estimate group differences regarding co-morbid diagnoses, Pearson's Chi-square test was used. In order to estimate the effect of CBT treatment, we used a linear mixed effects model (LME)  [63] , with CY-BOCS scores (baseline, week 7, and week 14) as the dependent variable (over continuous time). Fixed effects were site (grand mean centered), weeks from baseline, the presence or absence of tic symptoms, and interaction of tics with time. We included in the model a random intercept and linear slope. All analyses were conducted using SPSS version 22, except we fitted the LME model using PROC MIXED in SAS Statistical Software, Version 9.4 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). Tests were two-tailed, and a p value <0.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance.

sections.title: Results
sections.text:
Tic symptoms, present or past, were identified in 80 participants (29.9%) who were included in the OCD + tic group. The OCDtic group contained 188 participants (70.1%).

The groups did not differ with respect to age (t = -0.205, p = 0.838), but subjects in the OCD + tic group had earlier OCD onset (M = 10.92, SD = 3.19) compared to those without tic symptoms (M = 11.94 SD = 2.87; U = 4912.00, p = 0.040). There was a higher percentage of males in the OCD + tic group than in the OCDtic group (χ 2 = 8.47, p = 0.004; Table  1 ).

We did not find any between-group differences in baseline OCD severity based on CY-BOCS (p = 0.176). The OCD + tics group had significantly greater OCD-related functional impairment according to the COIS parent and child report. The OCD + tics group also scored higher on the CBCL externalizing and ASSQ measures (Table  1 ). In addition, youth with co-morbid tic symptoms more frequently had co-morbid ADHD, as expected, but they also, surprisingly, more frequently had social anxiety disorder. No between-group differences were found with respect to other co-morbid disorders (Table  1 ).

For OCD symptom categories, significant differences were found between groups (see Fig.  1 ), with those having tic symptoms scoring higher in the following CY-BOCS categories: hoarding obsessions (χ 2  The OCD + tics group endorsed two items related to "not just right experiences" more frequently than did the OCDtics group. The item "Uncomfortable sense of incompleteness or emptiness when rituals aren't performed in a certain way ('just right')" was experienced by 60.0% of those with co-morbid tic symptoms as opposed to 38.8% of those without tic symptoms, χ 2 (1, N = 268) = 10,156, p = 0.001. The other item, "Need to do things (e.g., touch or arrange) until it feels 'just right,'" was experienced by 53.8% of those with tic symptoms compared to 30.3% of those without tic symptoms, χ 2 (1, N = 268) = 13.172, p < 0.001.

Results from LME analysis showed that the fixed effects of time were significant (t[248] = -21.2, p < 0.001) showing symptom reduction over time. The interaction of tics with treatment was not significant (t[237] = 1.02, p = 0.309), indicating that both groups benefited equally from CBT (Table  2 ).

sections.title: Discussion
sections.text:
This study is, to our knowledge, the largest to date to examine the differences in clinical presentation and CBT treatment efficacy in child and adolescent OCD patients with and without co-morbid tic symptoms. Another advantage of this study is that the sample had not received any treatment for OCD for at least six months before CBT started. This study found, first and foremost, that a large group of children and adolescents with OCD suffer from co-morbid tic symptoms (current or past; 29.85%). In agreement with our hypothesis, tic symptoms were more common in boys and were correlated with earlier age of OCD onset. We saw no differences between groups in respect to initial OCD severity, although the OCD + tics group was more likely to suffer from OCD-related impairment. With respect to the profile of co-morbid symptoms, the OCD + tic group also had more severe autism spectrum symptoms, along with more frequent diagnoses of ADHD and social anxiety disorder. We also found that the OCD + tics group differed in terms of the presentation of OCD symptoms. No difference was found in the efficacy of OCD treatment between groups. As expected, a significant gender difference was found in the group of children and adolescents with OCD and comorbid tic symptoms, where 62.5% were male compared to 43.1% in the OCD-only group. The gender difference found here is even higher than that found in a recent study  [16] , which could in part have resulted from the use of different assessments to measure tic symptoms.

In line with our hypothesis, we found an age difference in the emergence of OCD between the group having OCD with tic symptoms and the OCD-only group. As measured with CY-BOCS we found no elevated OCD severity in the group having OCD with tic symptoms, in line with our hypothesis and with previous research in this age group  [15, 16] . On the other hand, though functional impairment as measured with COIS was considerable in both groups, contrary to our hypothesis we found the OCD + tic group to be significantly more impaired, indicating that tic symptoms may be a clinical indicator of reduced functioning. As this group also had higher co-morbidity of ADHD and social anxiety disorder, we cannot rule out that these comorbidities could be affecting the impairment level. In clinical samples, impairment has been found to correlate with the severity of OCD symptoms, but our results indicate that this relation is different for OCD subgroups with and without tic symptoms. One possible reason for this difference is that COIS is not good at differentiating between OCDrelated impairment and impairment caused by other factors, possibly including that caused by tics.

We found that OCD symptom presentation differed between groups, especially regarding compulsions, where the OCD + tic group scored higher for all compulsions except mental compulsions. Hoarding and symmetry obsessions were also more common in this group. Previous results are inconsistent regarding differences in OCD symptom presentation, but generally OCD patients with tic symptoms have lower rates of measured obsessions and  compulsions  [8, 16, 24, 25] , while we found this group to have generally higher rates, primarily in compulsions. The reason for these differences between previous work and our study is unclear, but it could be caused by differences in sample composition. Therefore, caution should be taken before concluding anything based on existing research about differences in OCD symptoms between these subgroups of OCD patients. One consistent pattern across this and previous studies, though, is that tic symptoms correlate with hoarding symptoms, higher rates of impairment, and an earlier age of OCD onset  [64] . Also, in agreement with previous research  [26, 27] , we found that OCD patients with tic symptoms more frequently report having "not just right experiences" than those without tic symptoms.

As for co-morbidity and consistent with the study by Lewin et al. 2010, we found that the OCD group with tic symptoms had significantly higher rates of ADHD than the OCD group without tic symptoms. This association was somewhat expected, as studies have indicated high co-morbidity between tics and ADHD and have suggested that tic disorder could mediate the co-morbidity between OCD and ADHD  [30] . However, a recent study based on SRI nonresponders did not confirm this relationship  [16] . Children and adolescents with OCD and symptoms of tics scored higher on all scales of the ASSQ, measuring subclinical autism spectrum traits, confirming earlier studies connecting autism spectrum traits with tics and ADHD  [31] . The fact that social anxiety disorder was more common in the OCD group with tic symptoms could be related to the finding that this group was more functionally impaired and/or had a higher load of ASD symptoms. Earlier studies, however, do not support these suggestions  [15, 16] .

In agreement with our hypothesis, we did not identify any difference in response to CBT treatment between groups. CBT seems to be just as effective for children with OCD and co-morbid tic symptoms as it is to those with OCD and no tic symptoms. This is in line with findings in other recent studies comparing treatment efficacy for these groups  [16, 38, 39, 41] . These consistent findings indicate that CBT is equally effective in addressing the OCD symptoms of both groups despite possible phenomenological, neurobiological and genetic differences. However, the possible differential mechanisms involved in the CBT process for the two groups are not clear. It has been suggested that tic-related OCD might require longer treatment sessions of exposure and response prevention due to the elevated "just right" compulsions  [37] . It might be that the CBT program in this study have provided adequate time and flexibility for clinicians to ensure individual adaptations to specific symptom profiles. Following this line of reasoning it is possible that different forms of CBT (e.g., shorter duration of sessions, etc.) would result in different outcome of the two groups. Also, methodological limitations regarding a reliable distinction between complex motor tics and compulsions resulting in poorly defined groups, could possibly mask any true difference in treatment outcome.

The primary strength of this study is the large sample used, along with the comprehensive assessment of OCD symptoms and co-morbid symptoms. Another strength is that the sample received no treatment for OCD for at least six months prior to treatment start as well as CBT is not mediated by other forms of treatment. A limitation to this study is that the dataset used is limited to the summary statistics of the DSM-IV diagnoses included in KSADS, with no distinction between motor and vocal tics. This as well as problems of power do not allow us to examine any differences in co-morbidity and CBT outcome based on the nature of the tic disorders. Another limitation of this study is the homogeneity of the Scandinavian sample, which could limit its generalizability. Furthermore, a limitation is that we used K-SADS to assess tic symptoms, which provides less detailed information than the Yale Global Tic Severity Scale (YGTSS).

In conclusion, children and adolescents with OCD and co-morbid tic symptoms differ from those with OCD and no symptoms of tics in several aspects of clinical presentation but not with respect to response to CBT or to OCD severity. The high rates of co-morbidity with ADHD and higher frequency of autism spectrum traits in this group are especially noteworthy for clinicians, who need to be aware of the greater functional impairment seen in this group even though the group showed no differences in OCD symptom severity.
